positive.review: At first this game feels like pure horror, dark rooms, creepy sounds and ghosts hunting you down. But once you learn how each ghost behaves it turns into more of a survival game with purpose. You're not just scared anymore. You're investigating, testing, and figuring out what kind of ghost you're dealing with.

This is a very fun game.
But this is a very hard game to recommend, it has some massive flaws. So if you're reading the review read it closely.

If you play this game blind with all new players, even with the tutorial, it will be an exercise in walking into a house, being very very bored and then suddenly dying. This is because the game does not sufficiently communicate it's mechanics at all and they are not easily intuitable in the time it is reasonable to allow it to make it's impression.

I also think forcing new players to use worse equipment that is much less reliable and readable, while they don't know what it does, rather than building that into the difficulty curve and restricting higher levels to using it is a very... interesting(derogatory) choice.

If you are willing to have everyone watch a couple of ten minute tutorial videos on youtube to learn the barest basics, if you're willing to play a patient slow moving puzzle game and willing to grind until you have equipment a ghost will actually interact with in a reasonable time period, then I think I can recommend Phasmophobia to you, quite enthusiastically. 
It's a game that grows on you.

The Voice Chat is hot garbage though, drop off is way too sharp, the global chat is way to quiet and you can't rebalance the audio in any way. I like location based voice chat I just think the implementation is very very bad.

This game is good and it's not good at the same time.  It's arguably the original ghost hunting game, and it's still the best one in terms of mechanics.  

But if you want to be blunt, the game has an extremely slow development time.  Even when new things come out, it's not like they are perfect.  My friends and I have found bugs in the new map (Nell's Diner) within the first two weeks of playing it, and we weren't trying to break the game.

And let's be really honest.  This game has only 24 items total in the game.  Twenty four.  But somehow the game needs a massive, confusing UI interface to manage these 24 items as if it was the most sophisticated thing in the universe.  There are RPGs with hundreds of items, where your character has at least six equipment slots, and you can easily buy and sell items in just seconds.  But this game needs a dedicated buy/sell screen, a separate equipment management screen, and a quick loadout screen.

Your objective is to use different equipment to determine which of 24 spirits is haunting a location solo or up to teams of 4. Monitor sanity level and escape the hunting ghost when it is low enough. That said, the community‚Äôs biggest request is still the same: the game needs bug fixes and stability improvements more urgently than new content drops. Interaction bugs, ghost behavior hiccups, glitches, that get more noticeable the longer you play. Many of us are hoping the Devs prioritize stability before layering on more systems. It would go a long way for new players, especially veterans who‚Äôve been here since the older builds.

The badge system could use a little love. I enjoy earning achievements in this game, but some of the long grind badges don‚Äôt feel equal to the effort they demand.
